The sun always follows the moon, and each day it is 48,880 yojanas closer. The sun and moon are also like this when they are farthest apart.

When they are closest, the sun covers the moon by three yojanas and one yojana and one-third. For this reason, on the fifteenth day, when the moon is completely covered by the sun, it is the day of the dark half.

The sun and moon are also 48,880 yojanas away from each other. The sun and moon open up by three yojanas each day, and also one yojana and one-third. For this reason, on the fifteenth day, the moon is completely clear and full, and the world calls it the full white half.
If the sun and moon move farthest apart, at that time the moon is full, and the world says it is the full white half.
If the sun and moon move together, this is called moving together, and the world says it is the full black half.

If the sun follows the moon behind, the sunlight shines on the moonlight, and the moonlight is coarse, so it is illuminated and gives rise to shadows. This moon shadow then obscures the moon itself, so the latter part of the moon is seen as not full.
For this reason, it gradually covers up, until on the fifteenth day it completely covers the moon, and when it follows behind, this is called the black half.
If the sun moves in front of the moon, the sun opening up the moon is also like this.
When it is full on the fifteenth day, it is called the bright half.
